What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: An advanced introductory knowledge of Electrostatics and Magnetostatics, Electrodynamics, Special Relativity and Relativistic E&M, and some interesting points of Quantum Mechanics (Stern-Gerlach experiments, the Bloch Sphere, GHZ state)
electro/magnetostatics, electrodynamics, introduction to special relativity and quantum mechanics
A strong vector-calculus-based introduction to E&M, infused with the very basics of special relativity, and a conceptual foundation of QM.
knowledge of E&M, special relativity, and intro to quantum mechanics
How to make the best of difficult, time-constrained exams where perfect performance isn't an option.

You know. Intro E&M and some super basic quantum stuff. Electrostatics, magnetostatics, then Maxwell's equations. Light waves. Special relativity. The quantum stuff was really just looking at Stern Gerlach devices and deriving the Bloch sphere.

I gained an understanding of what electrodynamics is, what light is, why magnetic fields exist, and the interface between E&M and relativity. I also gained some Quantum Mechanics intuition that will be helpful later on.

Electromagnetism presented at a higher mathematical rigor (electrostatics, magnetostatics, electrodynamics, Maxwell's equations, wave equation and light formulated in terms of vector calculus), introduction to special relativity motivated by E&M, and an intuitive introduction to quantum mechanics. Particular emphasis was given to the construction of special relativity and quantum mechanics from their fundamental bases, providing a good working background.
Topics in electromagnetism up to Maxwell's equations for dynamics problems. Introduction to special relativity and then to quantum mechanics/

I learned to tackle complicated physical problems by simplifying them and applying experiemntally verified theorems. I gained much deeper insight into the physical world, especially the counterintuitive laws governing regimes that are alien to my daily life. I learned to interperet light waves through Maxwell's equations, I learned the basis for the theory of special relativity, and I learned the foundation for the theory of quantum mechanics.
Greater understanding of E&M concepts and problem solving techniques.
Electromagnetism, Relativity, and some Quantum Mechanics

Thorough and intensive development of classical and relativistic electricity and magnetism, the special theory of relativity, and a brief introduction to fundamental ideas of quantum mechanics. Insights into the order in which the laws of electricity and magnetism were discovered and the thought process behind them, as well as how E&M led to the development of special relativity. Practical multivariable calculus skills and lots of experience with 3D vector and scalar fields and 3D integration.

I developed a deeper understanding of the principles of electromagnetism and a very basic understanding of special relativity. I also learned the most basic concepts related to the mathematical expressions of quantum mechanics.

I developed a full understanding of the basics of electro/magneto -statics, electro/magneto -dynamics, and relativity, and had a solid introduction to quantum mechanics. I also developed my problem solving skills by continuously doing problems. Additionally, when there were problems that were tricky in nature, I was able to improve my creativity in solving the problems by finding cool ways of working around the logic.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Harris was very knowledgeable, and his lectures moved in a way that was internally consistent and made sense (sans the occasional typo). As for PSETs, they were much more manageable than last semester--but I think that was mostly a function of Griffiths being a really good textbook. 
Weaknesses: Grading and feedback came very slowly, and that was especially frustrating when trying to figure out where my understanding was incomplete and where I stood in the class. Also, when they happened, most of the TF office hours I went to were not the most helpful.

Strengths - covers a good selection of topics from E+M and manages to have time to introduce some more advanced/interesting topics
Weaknesses - some pset problems required knowledge from unassigned chapter sections (fortunately these never appeared on any exam but were very annoying, nonetheless

Strengths: 1. the E&M content was chosen at the right level of difficulty for someone with AP Physics C background, and was not too challenging but not too boring either. 2. the grading was generous, which is a much-needed plus given the difficulty of the material. Weaknesses: 1. special relativity being taught in 261 and not 260 meant that our exploration into QM was shorter than one would've liked; it would have been better to cover special relativity in more detail in 260 instead. 2. Prof Harris's delivery of content in lectures can get dull occassionally, especially since his slides while helpful are extremely dense - although that might just be the Zoom fatigue speaking.
I don't know. It's an intro physics class. You do the intro physics stuff. There's nothing to write home about, and I think that's just sort of the way it is with this kind of class.

Strengths: professor Harris as a lecturer, class culture, rigor of homework assignments

Weaknesses: tests mostly consisted of problems with simple ideas but messy and brutal mathematics (e.g. find the magnetic field inside an n-gon of constant current). I would have liked to see problems focused on subtlety of physical intuition.

This class provides a solid background in electromagnetism while introducing special relativity and quantum mechanics, two pillars in modern physics. Additionally, the material is presented with some sophistication and mathematical methods are developed as needed including vector calculus, differential equations, the Dirac delta, and complex vector spaces. The attention given by Professor Harris to motivate relativity and quantum mechanics was a particular strength. I found it to be a unique perspective that builds intuition. In terms of improvements, it would be helpful to have more time on tests (scanning was always rushed and stressful). Furthermore, the TAs were generally not very helpful and would not take time to explain concepts; working with other students was super beneficial.

I found the lecture format slightly difficult for notetaking, and while lectures were interesting I wish there had been slightly more focus on problem solving. Reading the textbook was definitely what taught me how to do the homework and the exams.

The material in this course was fascinating and compelling, and the focus on building intuition provided me with a stronger foundation for exploring more complicated physics in the future. However, the course required knowledge of advanced techniques in math that weren't addressed thoroughly in class. Since students had varied levels of preparation from high school calculus classes, lacking a multivariable background would greatly decrease the difficulty of this course. For this reason, more worked examples and resources might improve this course.
Very nice course overall, extremely enjoyed the motivations for relativity.

I really enjoyed this class, more than I enjoyed 260 last semester. Professor Harris introduced some topics in a truly beautiful way, especially deriving the Theory of Relativity from Maxwell's equations. The class was well structured and taught, and the exams and homework were pretty fair. Overall a great class.

This course is well organized and covers the challenging content clearly. Lectures usually discuss and develop all content required for assigned problems, except a couple instances were problems were not relevant to the lecture content. The thorough treatment of the chain of discoveries and amendments to the laws of E&M and how from them special relativity can be deduced is particularly helpful and illuminating, as well as the thorough discussion of quantum states and the spaces that represent them.

The strength of this course was, arguably, the textbook for Electromagnetism (Griffiths), and the lectures were better than last semester. I also want to make a shoutout to one Peer Tutor (Eliza), who was incredibly helpful and patient during office hours. The weaknesses of the course include poor feedback that usually came late, and perhaps lectures that were unengaging because of extensive mathematical manipulations. Perhaps this could be improved by giving students a handout with the mathematical dirty work and show the results and some key steps instead of the whole derivation. Another weakness was the organization of many office hours during the course. I wish the office hours of the instructor had been put in a day farther from the day in which PSets were posted since this meant that I was unable to ask questions about the material to the instructor.

Another issue that I would like to point out is that exams seem to be testing how well we can apply examples from class and the book as opposed to testing whether we actually understood the material. Throughout the academic year, both for 260 and 261, I felt that I was learning how to solve tests prepared by this instructor instead of learning physics.

The lectures were clear and concise. The information conveyed by them was very helpful in improving my understanding of the subject.

One thing that could be improved is that the lecture slides occasionally double up the panels, and some of the things written become special characters when uploaded to Canvas. If the could be fixed, then the slides would be easier to use.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Recorded lectures were helpful
Everything was fine.

I cant think of a practice that didnt succeed. The course seemed like it had always been taught over zoom, professor Harris was extremely good at giving online lectures, and the course progressed seemlessly.

The posting of the lecture slides and recordings of lectures were helpful for review! TA office hours were often canceled and I preferred to work with other students. I would have liked a central location (e.g. Zoom link, Gathertown room) in which we would be able to meet.

The lecture style was engaging and transisitioned well to the online format. The only issue was the format of the slides. The progressive animation made it difficult to review lecture notes after the fact, as each lecture consisted of upward of 100 slides. If this class were ever to be remote again, I would hope to see the format of the slides change to make them easier to review.

It was good that exam times were flexible. There were no measures aiming at ameliorating the situation stemming from the COVID-19 pandemic besides that one. I wish there had been more chances for us students to interact with each other, but that was not necessarily the instructor's fault.

I felt that the online environment worked for this course. There were an ample number of zoom office hours with the professor and the TA's, and the course itself was very straightforward. The professor also always incorporated a bit of time into the lectures to accept questions, which was helpful since it allowed the lectures to flow more smoothly.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If the topics listed are ones that interest you and you're willing to put in a good deal of work and grinding outside of class, you will get a lot out of it. The discussions we had on relativity and quantum were very interesting, and our E&M work came together nicely. Midterms were not impossible this semester--especially compared to 260.  However, this class is not for everyone. If the description for this class and the reviews you're reading right now sound like a challenge you're excited to take on and a way to build on the calculus-based physics you already know, go for it and godspeed. If not, don't.

Pretty much only if you have a strong physics background or a physics major. I really enjoyed learning about topics like special relativity and quantum mechanics, but I'm probably not going to be a physics major and had to put in a lot of time into this class - think I might have been better off taking 200/201.

If you took PHYS 260, enjoyed its emphasis on derivations and equations, and want a more rigorous foundation of E&M than just AP Physics C, take this course. It'll definitely give you a better conceptual understanding of E&M and QM than any other course in the intro sequence, making it more than worth the extra effort.

As a math major with non-extraordinary physics preparation, I didn't do great in the course but I enjoyed it a lot. In retrospect, one of the other intro sequences would have been a better fit for my prep and goals.
I mean, it's an intro to physics. You get what you expect, and nothing more.
Yes, if this student was a math major or a physics major primarily interested in theory.

Definitely! If you are interested in physics and have a decent background, this is the sequence to take. Although you might see less electromagnetism than you would like, the introductions to special relativity and quantum mechanics are strong additions to this course. The level at which material is presented and the accompanied mathematical formalism will widely prepare you for further studies in physics. The other students in this class also will motivate your intellectual curiosity and lead to some cool discussions! I have made some amazing friends.

Yes! This was my first college-level physics course. 261 investigated aspects of the physical world that were abstract and fascinating. Learning about the underlying behavior of the universe through a mathematical language will make anyone who takes this course love physics.
Yes if you want to learn as much physics as possible, at the (temporary) cost of confidence and time
Yes, as long as you enjoy physics.
Yes! If they want a solid introduction to EM/Relativity/QM and want to major in physics or related fields, absolutely.
I would recommend it to students seeking a more thorough and mathematically sophisticated treatment of the usual introductory physics topics.

I would not recommend this course to another student at Yale. There is no need to go for this much harder course when they can take 200/1 for any purposes, including for the requirements of the Physics major. Many students in this class are beyond brilliant, and that alone made me feel that I should have taken 200/1 to avoid losing my passion for the subject matter. 

If the student does not intend to pursue the physics major, it is unreasonable to take 260/1 for fun. Maybe Professor Girvin will provide a different approach, but I would go for the safe option which is to take it easy on yourself.

I would highly recommend this course to other students. With a decent math and physics background, this class is really straightforward. The principles taught in the class, although complicated at first, become simpler and seem more elegant with each use. In a weird way, I found that, although the material is at a higher level than Phys 260, the actual physics done is simpler and easier to follow and only looks intimidating at first. For students who want a challenge, and are eager to learn physics at a high level, I highly recommend this course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Reading textbook
Live lecture was also recorded
Lectures were also recorded for convenience and lecture slides were posted on Canvas.
Lectures were also recorded.
Collaborative problem sets and office hours
Lectures were recorded.
I also made use of the lecture notes and the recorded lectures.
